Pause Mode for the Bikemap Mobile App

Introduction

In my role as a Product Manager at Bikemap, I undertook a significant project known as "Pause Mode." This project was particularly exciting, as it allowed me to leverage my background as both a Product Designer and Product Manager.

Key Points

  • Recording cycling activity is a vital feature in the Bikemap app.
  • Many cyclists take breaks during their rides for various reasons.
  • The absence of a pause functionality in the Bikemap Bike Computer led to inaccuracies in ride recordings resulting in unrealistic performance data and visible GPS spikes on routes.
  • We introduced a pause functionality to address this issue.

Project Timeline and Collaboration

The Pause Mode project took off in December 2022, with initial planning and pitching, and was successfully developed and shipped in February 2023. Throughout the project, I collaborated with a cross-functional team, including another designer, iOS and Android developers, backend developers, as well as marketing and business stakeholders.

My Contributions

  • I played a dual role as both a product manager and product designer.
  • I pitched the project and convinced management stakeholders to make space for it in our roadmap.
  • I initiated the project, creating initial designs and user flows.
  • A colleague designer delivered the high-fidelity prototypes.
  • Multiple iOS and Android developers were involved in building the feature.

Project Goals

The Pause Mode project had several key objectives:

  1. Improve Data Quality
    Enhance the accuracy of recorded routes, eliminating the need for users to include breaks in their recordings or split their routes.
  2. Scope Management
    Given time constraints, we aimed to keep the scope minimal.
  3. Reduce Support Workload
    The project aimed to decrease the volume of support requests related to the missing pause feature.
  4. Boost User Satisfaction
    Pause Mode was the most requested feature, and implementing it would improve user satisfaction.
  5. Targeted Adoption
    We expected an adoption rate of 20%, aligning with the anticipated user need.

Research and Discovery

Our journey began with user feedback. We closely monitored customer requests through a feedback tool called "Canny." These requests highlighted the significance of a pause feature. Guerilla user interviews and stakeholder discussions further validated the need for Pause Mode.

Key Insights

  • Users wanted to pause their rides for various reasons, such as breaks for eating, resting, and exploring.
  • Accurate performance data and battery conservation were significant concerns.
  • Technical limitations posed challenges in implementing a proper pause mode.

Iteation and Design

The design phase involved brainstorming various solution scopes, including Pause Mode for Recording, Navigation, or both, and manual vs. auto pause options. We planned marketing efforts in parallel and determined the final scope based on prototypes and user feedback.

Tools Used

  • Figma for designing wireframes and prototypes.
  • Overflow for communicating technical details to engineers.
  • Jira for project setup and development planning.
  • Confluence for comprehensive project documentation.
  • Loom for asynchronuous feedbach sessions, status updates and walkthroughts.

Testing and Validation

The testing phase involved discussions with engineers and user flow validation using Overflow. Usability testing with high-fidelity prototypes in Figma helped refine the design. Adjustments were made based on user feedback and QA testing during the Release Candidate phase.

Incorporated Feedback

  • Refined copywriting to be more concise and clear.
  • Extended notification timeout to improve readability.
  • Deferred some features for the roadmap, like auto-pause.
  • Addressed the issue of live metrics during a pause state.

Implementation and Development

Development was relatively straightforward, as the functionality was already present. However, iOS and Android teams had different schedules. The project was in collaboration with the marketing team to ensure users were informed about the upcoming feature.

Technical Constraints

  • Limitations in backend capabilities for saving GPS timestamps.
  • Mobile clients couldn't save multilegged routes to servers.
  • Scope adjustments due to QA findings during development.

Results and Impact

The results of the Pause Mode project were promising. Users responded positively, even reinstalling the app after learning about the feature through the newsletter. Support requests related to the missing pause feature decreased significantly, and the adoption rate met expectations.

Key Outcomes

  • Positive user reactions and app installs.
  • Reduced support requests.
  • Adoption rate of around 20%.
  • Plans to address additional issues in the future.

Lessons Learned

Reflecting on the project, it highlighted the complexities behind seemingly simple features. As a Product Manager with a UX background, it required constant balancing between user-friendliness and timely release. Effective communication was crucial to convey the complexities to stakeholders.

Takeaways

  • Shipping a feature with some limitations can be better than delaying perfection.
  • Getting engineers excited about challenging features requires strong communication and C-Level support.
  • Pausing Mode was an essential addition for users, even with its limitations.

Conclusion

In summary, the Pause Mode project appeared straightforward on the surface but had underlying complexities. We successfully reduced the scope to deliver a working feature on time. The feature was well-received, and adoption rates aligned with expectations.

Key Highlights

  • Complexity beneath a seemingly simple feature.
  • Successful delivery of a working feature in a short time.
  • Positive user response and reduced support requests.
  • Plans for addressing remaining issues in future iterations.
